The aim of the game is to produce a pair of mutually orthogonal Latin squares. A latin square is a grid of N rows by N columns. Each row and column must contain one of every value from 1 to N. 
 
For example if N = 3, each row and column must contain 1, 2, 3, meaning each row will differ from on another as will each column. 
 
When checking if a pair of Latin squares are mutually orthogonal, each position in The first Latin square will be paired with the corresponding position in the second. Creating a collection of paired positions. For the squares to be mutually orthogonal all pairs must unique and every possible pair must be accounted for. 
 
For example if N=3 all of the following pairs must be found (1,1), (1,2), (1,3), (2,1), (2,2), (2,3), (3, 1), (3,2), (3,3).

Leonhard euler, a famous mathematician from the 1700's whom worked with Latin squares for much of his research, was tasked to take 36 officers of different regiment and rank, placing 1 of each in every row and every column, essentially create a mutually orthogonal Latin square of order 6. 
 
He eventually came to the conclusion that producing a MOLS of order 6 was impossible, making the claim that they were only possible for odd numbers and multiples of 4. He was correct that order 6 is impossible, however the rest his claim was disproved as in 1959, as a MOLS of order 22 was produced which is neither odd or a multiple of 4. This known as the Euler conjecture.

 
If you wish to attempt to prove Euler wrong again and produce a pair of mutually orthogonal Latin squares of order 6, please attempt the game mode order 6. This follows the standard rules of the application however solve will not be able to assist you. 
 
Hint: It's impossible to do, Good luck
